SASKATCHEWAN ARCHIVES QUESTIONNAIRES

No. 2

PIONEER EXPERIENCES: A GENERAL QUESTIONNAIRE

A word of explanation to the Person answering this questionnaire:

It is difficult to measure a general questionnaire on pioneer life because no individual who is asked to answer it has exactly the same experiences as another. Some of the questions here will not apply to your experiences; others may prove impossible for you to answer, so don't worry about leaving blank spaces. Use extra sheets of paper if there is not sufficient space to answer the questions. Don't hesitate to give details or describe particular events, if they help to answer the questions.

This questionnaire is intended for persons who lived in Western Canada before 1914, and may be answered by anyone who has personal experience of the pioneer years whether born in this province or not.

If more than one member of the family can answer the questions, they should write them on separate sheets or apply for a separate questionnaire.

Other Questionnaires

Saskatchewan Archives Questionnaire No. 1, entitled "Pioneer Diet: What Did Western Canadian Pioneers Eat?" is still being circulated. If you have not already answered this, and would be willing to do so, please put a check mark here and one will be sent to you.

Saskatchewan Archives questionnaires on other subjects will be prepared at a later date. Some of these are listed below. Please mark the ones you would be willing to answer.

All questionnaires

All questionnaires will be preserved in the Saskatchewan Archives Board's Office at the University of Saskatchewan as part of the Permanent record of our Province. Please send your completed questionnaire to:

11. What did your friends and relatives think of your decision to come to Western Canada? From what I gathered by listening to conversation between my parents, their people in the East thought they were going to the "ends of the Earth" and would probably never be heard from again.

12. Did you travel by yourself or with a party (family, friends or other group)? My Father, Mother and Brother drove with teams (wagons) from Melita Man. to the ranch. I came late by train to Edmonton, continuing by team to the ranch.

13. What means of transportation did you use? My Father hired a heavy team and driver from Ball, Livingstone. We left Lytton about 9 a.m., after driving some distance, the driver put his feet on the dashboard of the buckboard and shook his lines and said "Go on Boys." The "Boys" went on and on and on over poor, rough frozen roads.

14. What incidents of the journey West do you remember? (People you met on the way, meetings with Indians, adventures on the journey, accidents or other excitement etc.). It was November but very little snow; it was just a trail not a road, we reached "Home" about 8 p.m. having stopped for dinner at Devils Lake at Barton making the journey of what was recorded to be 75 miles between 9 a.m. and 8 p.m., some team there Boys.

Question 14, nothing unusual I guess, after leaving Melita Hotel, so it was all strange and new to me.

15. Where did you first stay when you arrived in Saskatchewan? I'm not sure if I stopped for the night at the home of Mr. Meredith who was cattle buyer for the north country.

16. Where did you settle or take up land? Our range was about a mile from the present town of Precious Lake.

17. Mention any other places where you have lived since coming to Saskatchewan. My Brother filed on the first homestead taken over district in 1903 (think). My Father also had a purchased homestead later (he had already homesteaded in Man.) I lived on all three so can say I homesteaded 3 times. My family moved often but never more than 15 miles distant from our original home on the Assiniboine River.

18. How did you earn a living before coming to Western Canada? How after you came?

I helped with the cattle and horses, keeping track of where they were in summer, spent a great deal of time on a horse's back, and of course helped in the house.
11. What did your friends and relatives think of your decision to come to Western Canada? From what I gathered by talking to them, they thought it was a good move.

12. What means of transportation did you use? We left by train from Regina to Prince Albert, then by boat to Edmonton.

13. What happened during your journey? We encountered many challenges, including bad weather and difficult terrain.

14. How did you earn a living before coming to Western Canada? We started by working on a homestead and then moved to a town.

15. How did you earn a living after you came? We worked on a farm and then moved to a town.

16. Where did you settle or take up land? We settled in a small town near Edmonton.

17. Mention any other places where you have lived since coming to Western Canada. We lived in Regina, Prince Albert, and Edmonton.

18. How did you earn a living after you came? We worked on a farm and then moved to a town.

19. How did you earn a living before coming to Western Canada? We started by working on a homestead and then moved to a town.

20. How did you earn a living after you came? We worked on a farm and then moved to a town.
19. How often did you write to relatives or friends in your old home?

From my parents point of view, I think lack of news from home added to the hardships of pioneer life. Those who moved from East to West didn't have much to worry about except their struggles and they were often too proud to complain.

20. If you got married, give the name of your husband or wife along with the date and place of marriage.

Married in Sept. 1911 to J. A. McClure of Plateau Lake.

21. Did anyone else come to Saskatchewan because of your recommending it as a place to settle?

My Dad always said "encourage anyone coming West unless, as he put it, they were 'money hawks'! Otherwise they might be disappointed and blame the person who recommended they come. However an honest deal comes and takes an honest."

22. If other members of your family (brothers, sisters, parents, etc.) came West tell when they came and where they settled.

23. Is there any particular experience of pioneer days that stands out in your memory which you would like to record?

Traveling in the early years was limited to occasional trips to the nearest town or to the necessary moving about in connection with the business of earning a living. Neighbors were few and far between, so were visits. Some times we gathered for a dance if a musician could be found. As the country settled schools were built; then Church Service was held in the school before that service was held in the homes, whenever it was possible for the minister to get around. He had a large field. Even in the first years we were in back a large field.

Question 23

In answering this question, there were so many happenings in pioneer life that it is difficult to decide on which particular one to relate most difficulties of the day we took "in our stride" and promptly forgot. One that stands out in my memory concerns a chocolate-colored mare named "Cocoa" and happened during our second winter in Sask. We had a bunch of range horses bought from Montana the previous fall and because they were new on the range were wintering poorly. My Father had gone to Yorkton for supplies, my brother came in near evening and reported a horse down in a snow bank and he was unable to help her to her feet.

Albert - I went with team and stone boat, dragged the animal to a shed near the stables. Albert (17) thought she would pull through if she could be got to her feet, so we proceeded to fasten a pulley, get roped ed; Mother came to help, finally after several attempts we did manage to get the mare on her feet, just then Mother in the excitement got her finger on the pulley and it was badly hurt she went to the house, Albert finished with the animal then we too went to the house. It was now after 9 p.m., we had had no supper - were tired and cold, the sight of Mother's finger was too much for me, I bawled. Father returned next day, Mother's finger healed, "Cocoa" recovered, and all was well - until something else occurred.

34. Did any people move away from your district prior to 1914? What reasons did they have for moving?

A few of the early pioneer settlers moved to more settled and older districts. I think in several cases it was the impracticability of securing medical care for their wives and families that caused them to move closer to towns where such services could be found.

35. Did many people move away during the 1930s? Did many return?

No, there was no unusual movement; our district was a fortunate one, the land always gave good returns for those who would work it well; there was always some crop failure, but each return was another story.

36. If you or some member of your family have held public office, or have been active in any organizations, mention it here, giving dates wherever possible.

My public offices were very minor affairs & I believe I was once President of our local "Lodge Aid."

In the days of "Local Improvement Districts" my father was an interested member, and was often in charge of road repair gangs. He was also head of the school board and school trustees. The Wilson-Farley were in charge of Platina Post Office for some years 1910-11-12.

37. If you or any of your family or friends were "first" to have or do something in the district mention it here giving dates wherever possible. (Such as owning the first automobile, combine, organizing the first lodge, etc.)

I believe my brother bought the first horseless vehicle in about 1908 (Albert Speer). My husband had the first tractor in our neighborhood 1915.

The First Farmers Union Building and Bank was built at Todmorden about 1924 all volunteer labor and material.

Our School District - Corning, was suggested by Pat O'Brien who said it was a place in Mayo, Ireland. It was later thought to be his birthplace in Ireland. Many towns, villages, school districts etc., were named by people for the place they previously lived. Sturgis is an example, named by Fred Brooks for Sturgis Michigan. Eden Valley School is another, the old Whitebank Post Office kept by Mr. Paul, was suggested by Whitebank. They a group of people near by, the town of Peaceville was named for the Peace family in whose homestead the town is located.

34. Did any people move away from your district prior to 1914? What reasons did they have for moving?

A few of the early pioneer settlers moved to more settled and older districts. I think in several cases it was the impossibility of securing medical care for their wives and families that caused the ranchers to move closer to towns where such services could be provided.

35. Did many people move away during the 1930s? Did many return?

No, there was no unusual movement; our district was a fortunate one, the land always gave back returns for those who would work it well. There was always some crop failure, but each return was another story.

36. If you or some member of your family have held public office, or have been active in any organizations, mention it here, giving dates wherever possible.

My public offices were very minor affairs. I believe I was once President of our local "Lodge Aid." In the days of "Local Improvement Districts," my father was an interested member, and was often in charge of road repair gangs. He was also Secretary of the School and School Trustee. My mother and father were in charge of Platina Post Office for some years, 1910-11-12.

37. If you or any of your family or friends were "first" to have or do something in the district mention it here giving dates wherever possible. (Such as owning the first automobile, combine, organizing the first lodge, etc.)

I believe my brother was the first homesteader within 80 miles in about 1902 (Albert Specht). My husband had the first tractor in our neighborhood, 1918.

The first Farmers Union Building in town was built at Todmore about 1924 all volunteer labor and material.

Our School District - Cooper, was suggested by Pat O'Brien who said it was a place in Mayo. It was later thought to be his birthplace in Ireland. Many towns, villages, school districts, etc., were named by people for the places they previously lived. Sherry is an example, named by Fred Brooks for Sherry, Michigan. Eden Valley District is another, the old White Hawk Post Office kept by Mr. Peel, was suggested by White Hawk's wife, a grove of poplars near by, the town of Preciville was named for the Peace family, on whose Homestead the town is located.
34. Did any people move away from your district prior to 1942? What reasons did they have for moving?

A few of the early pioneer settlers moved to mine.

Settled and other districts, I think in normal cases it was the unprofitability & securing. Blackhead case for them were not homesteads, that caused the families to move closer to town or other small towns earlier.

5. Did many people move away during the 1930's? Did many return permanently?

No, there were no unusual movements. Our district was a farming area, the land always gave good returns. In this area, work was hard, there were always some early settlers who died due to the harsh conditions and climate.

My public offices were very minor offices and my father was an active member and was often in charge of the town hall. In the days of former superintendents and trustees, my father was also the town clerk and treasurer.

Our School District was named by Pat O'Brien who said if we were a place in Ireland it was called "Ballybreen," which means "many brown valleys," where they presumably lived. So we named our school district "Ballybreen."
